basics.name: Shekhar Devm Upadhyay
basics.label: Machine Learning Researcher
basics.summary: A passionate young researcher with a strong background in machine learning, mathematics and theoretical physics, and a proven track record of academic excellence.

work.name: Ericsson AB
work.summary: Developed and deployed multi-modal deep learning algorithms for anomaly detection and fault verdict prediction in Telecom Networks, using software logs and multi-variate time series, comparing against unimodal baselines.

work.name: SEB (Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken) AB
work.summary: Worked as a machine learning intern in the Advanced Analytics group at SEB, where I developed an adversarial machine learning model for Extractive Question Answering and built a RAG model for the same.

work.name: KTH Royal Institute of Technology
work.summary: Led tutorials, graded presentations, and facilitated learning in DD2380 Artificial Intelligence, enhancing my expertise in AI and mentoring skills.

_volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

courses: Introduction to the Philosophy of Science and Research Methodology
Artificial Intelligence and Multi Agent Systems
Statistical Methods in Applied Computer Science

awards.title: Tech Talent of the Year
awards.summary: Named Tech Talent of the Year 2023 by SEB and Universum for showcasing data analysis skills in a data analysis project identifying viable investments for SEB Greentech Venture Capital.

_publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
_publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

_publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
_publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

_publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
_publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

_projects.name: Quantum Computing
_projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
